repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
This PR contains:
 * Move struct, enum and union documentation so separate section
 * Extend definition of struct, enum and union also with actual usage in code - how to create and access. One big example was split into separate ones.
 * union part was moved out of tabs for better experience when tabs are switched
 * pointer to function section was expanded with examples

comment_data.body:
Following section/part contains mentions about `cdef` functions and extension types. In general this is wrong place and I think it should be moved:
1. `cdef` function part should be removed because it is better explained in different part - _Python functions vs. C functions_ section (maybe just do double check whether there is not something not mentioned elsewhere).
2. extension type part should be moved somewhere else - not sure where ...

I did not do this changes because I am not 100% sure what is the best. But I am willing to do it after suggestion from others...
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -128,75 +128,91 @@ the declaration in most cases:
                 cdef float *g = [1, 2, 3, 4]
                 cdef float *h = &f
 
-In addition to the basic types, C :keyword:`struct`, :keyword:`union` and :keyword:`enum`
-are supported:
 
-.. tabs::
+.. note::
 
-    .. group-tab:: Pure Python
+    There is also support for giving names to types using the
+    ``ctypedef`` statement or the ``cython.typedef()`` function, e.g.
 
-        .. literalinclude:: ../../examples/userguide/language_basics/struct_union_enum.py
+    .. tabs::
 
-        .. note:: Currently, Pure Python mode does not support enums. (GitHub issue :issue:`4252`)
+        .. group-tab:: Pure Python
 
-    .. group-tab:: Cython
+            .. code-block:: python
 
-        .. literalinclude:: ../../examples/userguide/language_basics/struct_union_enum.pyx
+                 ULong = cython.typedef(cython.ulong)
 
-        See also :ref:`struct-union-enum-styles`
+                 IntPtr = cython.typedef(cython.p_int)
 
-        .. note::
+        .. group-tab:: Cython
 
-            Structs can be declared as ``cdef packed struct``, which has
-            the same effect as the C directive ``#pragma pack(1)``.
+            .. code-block:: cython
 
-        Declaring an enum as ``cpdef`` will create a :pep:`435`-style Python wrapper::
+                ctypedef unsigned long ULong
 
-            cpdef enum CheeseState:
-                hard = 1
-                soft = 2
-                runny = 3
+                ctypedef int* IntPtr
 
-        There is currently no special syntax for defining a constant, but you can use
-        an anonymous :keyword:`enum` declaration for this purpose, for example,::
+.. _structs:
 
-            cdef enum:
-                tons_of_spam = 3
+Structs, Uions, Enums
+---------------------
 
-        .. note::
-            the words ``struct``, ``union`` and ``enum`` are used only when
-            defining a type, not when referring to it. For example, to declare a variable
-            pointing to a ``Grail`` struct, you would write::
+In addition to the basic types, C :keyword:`struct`, :keyword:`union` and :keyword:`enum`
+are supported:
 
-                cdef Grail *gp
+.. tabs::
 
-            and not::
+    .. group-tab:: Pure Python
 
-                cdef struct Grail *gp  # WRONG
+        .. literalinclude:: ../../examples/userguide/language_basics/struct.py
 
-.. note::
+    .. group-tab:: Cython
 
-    There is also support for giving names to types using the
-    ``ctypedef`` statement or the ``cython.typedef()`` function, e.g.
+        .. literalinclude:: ../../examples/userguide/language_basics/struct.pyx
 
-    .. tabs::
+    .. note::
 
-        .. group-tab:: Pure Python
+        Structs can be declared as ``cdef packed struct``, which has
+        the same effect as the C directive ``#pragma pack(1)``.
 
-            .. code-block:: python
+.. tabs::
 
-                 ULong = cython.typedef(cython.ulong)
+    .. group-tab:: Pure Python
 
-                 IntPtr = cython.typedef(cython.p_int)
+        .. literalinclude:: ../../examples/userguide/language_basics/union.py
 
-        .. group-tab:: Cython
+    .. group-tab:: Cython
 
-            .. code-block:: cython
+        .. literalinclude:: ../../examples/userguide/language_basics/union.pyx
 
-                ctypedef unsigned long ULong
+.. literalinclude:: ../../examples/userguide/language_basics/enum.pyx
 
-                ctypedef int* IntPtr
 
+.. note:: Currently, Pure Python mode does not support enums. (GitHub issue :issue:`4252`)
+
+Declaring an enum as ``cpdef`` will create a :pep:`435`-style Python wrapper::
+
+    cpdef enum CheeseState:
+        hard = 1
+        soft = 2
+        runny = 3
+
+There is currently no special syntax for defining a constant, but you can use
+an anonymous :keyword:`enum` declaration for this purpose, for example,::
+
+    cdef enum:
+        tons_of_spam = 3
+
+.. note::
+    In the Cython syntax, the words ``struct``, ``union`` and ``enum`` are used only when
+    defining a type, not when referring to it. For example, to declare a variable
+    pointing to a ``Grail`` struct, you would write::
+
+        cdef Grail *gp
+
+    and not::
+
+        cdef struct Grail *gp  # WRONG
 
 You can create a C function by declaring it with :keyword:`cdef` or by decorating a Python function with ``@cfunc``:

-            Structs can be declared as ``cdef packed struct``, which has
-            the same effect as the C directive ``#pragma pack(1)``.
+            .. code-block:: cython
 
-        Declaring an enum as ``cpdef`` will create a :pep:`435`-style Python wrapper::
+                ctypedef unsigned long ULong
 
-            cpdef enum CheeseState:
-                hard = 1
-                soft = 2
-                runny = 3

-        There is currently no special syntax for defining a constant, but you can use
-        an anonymous :keyword:`enum` declaration for this purpose, for example,::

-                tons_of_spam = 3
+Structs, Uions, Enums

comment_data.body:
This doesn't seem to appear in the generated output.

I also wonder if it should have a little more detail on two points:
* removes the empty space between members that C automatically to ensure that they're aligned in memory (just people that don't know what `#pragma pack(1)` does).
* the main use is that numpy structured arrays store their data in packed form, so a `cdef packed struct` can be used in a memoryview to match that.

comment_data.body: I think this PR at least needs an extra heading to separate it from the `structs/unions/enums` section. Not thought about the where it should be long-term

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
The following example shows declaring a ``ptr_add`` function pointer and assigning the ``add`` function to it:
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -634,7 +650,15 @@ parameters and has two required keyword parameters.
 Function Pointers
 -----------------
 
-Functions declared in a ``struct`` are automatically converted to function pointers.
+.. note:: Pointers to functions are currently not supported by pure Python mode. (GitHub issue :issue:`4279`)
+
+Following example shows declaring ``ptr_add`` function pointer and assigning ``add`` function to it:

comment_data.body:
There are already two sections discussing both extension types and C functions:
* C functions - I have removed this part. There is already full pledged section which mentions everything even better
* Extension types - There is another part mentioning that. I have merged them together and created separated heading for that.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
Those will have a behaviour very close to python classes (e.g. creating subclasses), but are faster. Typing variable
```

Not very important but I think we've used British/Australian/New Zealand spelling elsewhere
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -356,12 +316,29 @@ and is typically what one wants).
 If you want to use these numeric Python types simply omit the
 type declaration and let them be objects.
 
+Extention Types
+---------------
+
 It is also possible to declare :ref:`extension-types` (declared with ``cdef class`` or the ``@cclass`` decorator).
-This does allow subclasses. This typing is mostly used to access
-``cdef``/``@cfunc`` methods and attributes of the extension type.
+Those will have a behavior very close to python classes (e.g. creating subclasses), but are faster. Typing variable

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
as extension type is mostly used to access ``cdef``/``@cfunc`` methods and attributes of the extension type.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -356,12 +316,29 @@ and is typically what one wants).
 If you want to use these numeric Python types simply omit the
 type declaration and let them be objects.
 
+Extention Types
+---------------
+
 It is also possible to declare :ref:`extension-types` (declared with ``cdef class`` or the ``@cclass`` decorator).
-This does allow subclasses. This typing is mostly used to access
-``cdef``/``@cfunc`` methods and attributes of the extension type.
+Those will have a behavior very close to python classes (e.g. creating subclasses), but are faster. Typing variable
+as extention type is mostly used to access ``cdef``/``@cfunc`` methods and attributes of the extension type.

commit.message: [Docs] Refactor and extend structs, unions, enums, function pointer documentation in language basics userguide

repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

title: [Docs] Refactor and extend structs, unions, enums, function pointer documentation in language basics userguide
